body: For the gradescope test is_monotonicish([1, 2, 3, 4 , 3, 2, 1]) it says expected: 'True'. I don't know if that is the correct solution, but at least you get the points on gradescope, but I don't know if that is the behavior we want for this function.

title: Explanation of consistency in heuristics
body:
"A consistent heuristic function means that the values of
f(n) along any path are non-decreasing" is what is said on the slide, but I'm not exactly sure what that means for h(n).

comments.body:
In the example of graph-searching problem,  for arbitrary node `N` and its arbitrary successor `P` in the graph, the heuristic value `f(N)` of this node given by consistent heuristic functions `f( )`, is no greater than the step `cost` of getting to `P` plus `f(P)` ( where `f(P)` is the heuristics value of node `P`).

![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

If the heuristics functions satisfies this condition, we say this heuristics functions is `consistent heuristic function`. If not, we don't. 
HTH. :)

title: Iterative deepening search clarification
body:
I'm a bit confused what it means on slide 25 of lecture 2 that IDS is optimal if step costs are identical. 

Is step costs referring to how much the max depth to search to increases from iteration to iteration or does it refer to the transition cost between each state? 

Edit: 

If it means the cost of the transition. Doesn't the optimality also depend on how you increase the depth to go to , k , each time? I can see how for cases where you always increase the depth by 1 and all transitions have cost 1, it'll  be the optimal solution. 

However, if you increased the value of k by some number greater than the transition cost each time, don't you run the possibility finding a solution greater than the optimal solution?

comments.body: I think it means transition between states

title: Consistent Hueristic
body:
Hello,

I'm kinda confused on what this means exactly. The slides say it means that "the values of f(n) along any path are non-decreasing". 

Can someone first explain the difference between h(n) and f(n) in A* and then explain what this definition is saying? 

That would be greatly appreciated!
-Thanks

comments.body: When a heuristic functions is admissible and consistent, it will have these features in #41. Comment if you have further question, and hope this helps.

Thank you for taking the time to answer. Follow up:
If f(n) and h(n) are the same thing, how would it be non-decreasing along any path? Doesn't the heuristic get smaller and smaller as you get closer to the goal?

Thanks

I apologize for my mistake, `h()` and `f()` are not the same things, which are described in page `67`.
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

"A consistent heuristic function means that the values of f(n) along any path are non-decreasing". 

We now know `f(n) = g(n) + h(n)` so far, given by the definitions above. The reason why `f(n)` is non-decreasing, is because for any node, let say `n`, there will be `f(n) = g(n) + h(n)`, where `h(n)` is a heuristic value, an `ideal`, lowest cost from `n` to `Goal` (it can be the straight-line distance as slides define).  And, for any node that you are walking through from the starting node to goal node, the `f(n)` will at least be non-decreasing, due to the real cost from the current node to goal node is always non-lower than the heuristic of current node (it can be equal, when this heuristic is perfect).

Sry for my mistake before again, and hope this helps.

title: Does greedy best-search ever push a goal state?
body: When greedy best-first search reaches a goal state, does the goal state get pushed then popped, or does it just terminate immediately? I figured that it  just ends upon reaching a goal state, but can't confirm this in the textbook or lecture slides.

conversation.name: Does greedy best-search ever push a goal state?

comments.body: For greedy best (and other cost based searches) the goal state first gets pushed onto the frontier and then has to be popped in order to consider the search "complete". That is because even though it may on the frontier, its weight/priority can be updated in the priority queue if we find a path with a lower cost.

title: How do we get the priority from each element for USC?
body: I've been trying to assign the priority to each element for the implementation of UCS, but I can't find out how. What gives each task their priority, and how can I assign it to the frontier?

conversation.name: How do we get the priority from each element for USC?

comments.body:
If, by chance, you are inheriting `BreadthFirstSolver`, you will have to change the frontier to `PriorityQueue`.

If you are using `PriorityQueue` class from `pdpq.py`, you can assign the priority in `PriorityQueue` by doing using `add(task, priority=p)` where `p` is your priority. 

Take a look into `pdpq.py` for more details.

Thank you for answering so fast. I did that before, but when I do priority=self.frontier.get() it doesn't work, instead it returns the string of numbers. Maybe I'm not understanding where the priority is coming from.

In the case of UCS, the priority is the cost to a given node. We can get the cost to a given node using the ```get_cost``` function in the BFS class. BFS does not use this function but it was implemented there so other classes can inherit it or if you just want to copy it over for the other classes.

So say I have some state ```s``` and I want to add it to the frontier. Firstly, we will have the frontier be a ```PriorityQueue```, so say we do ```frtr = pdqpq.PriorityQueue()```. Then to get the cost of our state ```s``` we can use the ```get_cost``` function. Lastly, we can add it to the frontier with the cost/priority (they are the same in this case) ny doing what Mathew said with ```frtr.add(s, self.get_cost(s))```.

```priority=self.frontier.get()``` is missing an agreement inside the ```get()```. So say we want to get the priority of something **already** in the frontier. From our example before if we wanted to get the cost of the ```s``` we'd do ```s_priority = frtr.get(s)```.
Thank you for your thorough response, I got it to work and it's pretty close to what the professor had in class, so I guess I just need to polish it now. I hope you both have a good weekend.

title: Do arguments need to be passed in a specific order for games to run?
body:
Hello, I implemented the minimax algorithm and I am having a small issue. I do not know if it is something wrong with my code or the code provided.

When I run a command like: python connect383.py random mini 3x3 I get the following results: ![m.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

The number of states generated here makes me believe that I have implemented minimax correctly.

But if I make mini player 1 and random player 2 and run the command like this: python connect383.py mini random 3x3 I receive the following error:
![n.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/17cda193-edc7-46d3-9ee4-969df8027cb7/08d78e3c-29ca-41f7-b1fb-1f18662694d3/n.png)

My best guess based on this error is that for the first move of mini we never enter this if statement: ![o.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/17cda193-edc7-46d3-9ee4-969df8027cb7/6a82ef1e-351e-4c96-9231-2465da589eb9/o.png)

And because of this best_state and best_move are both just assigned and returned as None. I am just struggling to understand how this seems to work when mini is player 2, but does not when mini is player 1.

Thank you!

title: Regarding Evaluation Function
body:
In the comments for the code of the evaluation function it states: "This method must run in "constant" time for all states!"

In the assignment description this is given as an example: "For example, you might count all the
open-ended 2-in-a-rows for each player for a given state, and return the difference."

The rows, cols, and diags are stored in either lists or tuples, wouldn't the evaluation metric listed above run in linear time rather than constant since you would need to iterate through the list in order to see what pieces are where to determine if a run of length 2 or more is open-ended?

Thank you!

comments.body: The suggested evaluation function runs linear as a function of board size, which is a constant for a given problem across states.
That makes sense, thank you!

title: Which player to max for
body:
When implementing minimax I am unsure of how to keep track of which player I am maxing for and which I am minimizing for.

I could just add a variable to keep track but the starter code makes me think I am missing something really obvious so I thought I would ask here.

comments.body: state.next_player() is really useful for keeping track if the current player is a max or a min.
I do not see where I can get if the current player is a max or a min.

That was where I was confused, but it works out because player 2 always wants the score of the game to be more negative (and will choose to minimize utility because of that) while player 1 always wants to maximize. That means player 1 is always the max player and 2 always the min

title: State Generation Count
body:
Hello I just had a quick question regarding the counts of generated states. So with the provided code in connect383.py .successors() will generate all of the successors for a state and increment the generated count with the total number of successors generated. Now with this example in class:
![fffe4485810dc181d2e1b12340360867.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

In the middle state in the second row when we call .successors() our generated state count is increased by 3, but we do not explore the right most successor state due to pruning. In the most optimal case it seems better to generate successors 1 at a time and increment the count by 1 each time. This would cause us to not generate the last state since the pruning would occur prior and our generated states would only increment by 2. 

Is it fine that our generated count is being increased by 3 even if we are not exploring that last state at all since our count is counting generated states rather than explored states, and .successors() automatically increases the count when states are generated, or are we expected to find a way to generate these successor states one by one and only increase the generated count when a single state is generated?

Edit: In the comments of the code it states "N.B.: When exploring the game tree and expanding nodes, you must consider the child nodes
        in the order that they are returned by GameState.successors()." So it seems like we are expected to use .succesors() and the number of generated states would be incremented by 3 for the example above. And I believe this is also what the comment means by stating "we're trading optimality for gradeability here"

comments.body:
Good catch! Ideally, the `.successors()` function should have returned an iterator instead of an array of all successors. So yes, according to the provided code, the generated states count will get incremented by 3 for example you mentioned.
But it shouldn't be a big deal because the entire subtree below that 3rd successor will not be generated and will not add to the count. In the grand scheme of things, that extra count of one state won't matter.
Thank you!

title: MinimaxLookahead depth clarification
body: If the depth limit = the game tree depth, do we call the evaluation function, or just return the utility of the node. I see no point in returning evaluation, since if were already at the end of the tree we might as well take the most accurate way and return the utility instead, since the utility of a leaf node is the true value. For connect383, it also stands to reason that all leaf nodes are also at the same depth for any board, since it plays until both players have no moves left.

comments.body: You are correct in that if we have the ability to return the true utility, we should! The example in lecture also does this.
See #219

title: Rules for obstacles?
body:
Hello,

I'm confused on the rules for how the blocker pieces work. In a separate post I saw that blocker pieces can be placed at the top of the board, but when I run a test like:
\[\[-2, -2\],
\[0, 0\]\]

with random and human the code given by the project isn't able to detect that the board is full.

Running this board:
\[\[-2, -2, 0\],
\[0, 0, 0\],
\[0, 0, 0\]\]

with human and random uses only supplied code, and gives an error after the right column is filled. 

What exactly are the rules for blocker pieces? The instructions say that they are "obstacle pieces" so that implies to me that the same rules apply to them as regular player pieces do, so they should only be able to be placed like regular pieces and can't float / be at the top of the board. 

Can I please get some clarification?

Thanks!

comments.body:
Which post are you referring to?
My understanding is that blocker pieces cannot float and the examples you mention are invalid boards.
I will confirm this with the prof.
The replies in post #294 a TA in the comments said that a board with floating pieces is legal.

I see. The problem is that the supplied code detects that the board is full by checking if `_moves_left<=0`. The game is initialized with `_moves_left` = number of 0s in the initial board. As a result, the code is implicitly assuming that the blocker pieces don't float.
So, in the first example you mention, the game is initialized with `_moves_left=2`. That's why it is unable to detect that the board is full.

Thanks for catching this edge case!

But anyway, we won't test your code on boards with floating obstacles.
Great, thanks for clarifying!
Update: I'll make sure there aren't floating obstacles in the test cases since that doesn't work with the rest of the code.

In case it still doesn't work, you might want to change your interpreter path. The option to do that is usually at the bottom right of VS Code. Hope this helps!

title: Homework 4 calculations
body: I am getting tripped up on part (c) of the calculations portion where it asks to find the marginal probability of M = true. I initially thought to sum over all instances of m being true but that is just every entry in the table which would be far greater than one. if anyone could offer any suggestions of how to go about this problem it would be greatly appreciated!

comments.body:
Try using the following identity: 

If $$A$$ is a parent of $$B$$,
$$P(B=b) = \sum_{a \in \{true, false\}} P(A=a)P(B=b|A=a) $$

Or if there are two parents $$A_1, A_2$$,
$$P(B=b) = \sum_{a_1} \sum_{a_2} P(A_1=a_1, A_2=a_2)P(B=b|A_1=a_1,A_2=a_2) $$
If I understand correctly, you are summing up the rows where M=true. But you need a weighted sum, with a row's weight being the probably of that row itself being true.

What would happen in the case that $$A_1$$ is a parent of $$A_2$$ when calculating ![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
​?
Then A1 and A2 are not independent. In that case, joint probability P(A1, A2) = P(A1)P(A2|A1).

title: Independence Clarification from Fri. OH
body:
Hi all,

I wanted to give additional clarification about debates students had during office hours about independence.

Namely, student were asking if we have ![Screen%20Shot%202022-11-04%20at%203.56.38%20PM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
and we are asked to calculate P(B|A,E), why can't we do P(B|A,E)=P(B|A).

I said to simply look at the math to figure out why, but since students were a bit dissatisfied with that I'll explain further.

If $$P(B|A,E)=P(B|A)$$ then the following would need to hold:
$$P(B|A,E)=P(B,A,E)/P(A,E)=P(B,A)P(E)/(P(A)P(E))=P(B,A)/P(A)=P(B|A)$$ When I say look at the math, I mean think about why we cannot have $$P(B,A,E)/P(A,E)=P(B,A)P(E)/(P(A)P(E))$$ in the example above. I'd suggest reviewing lectures 12 and 13 (slide 38 helps with the overall question) to answer this.

As an additional note, I accidentally said in my office hours that B is independent from E if given A. I was mixing up some concepts and that is incorrect, see lecture 13 slide 38 to see why it is dependent.

title: Question on d-connectedness
body: In the causal DAG, we have a directed edge from Palate to Moxie, for example. So are these nodes d-connected or does it depend on which node you start from? Because starting from Moxie, there is no path back to Palate.

comments.body:
From lect 13 slide 28: "Two nodes (or sets of nodes) A and B are d-connected if there exists an **undirected**, collider-free path between A and B; otherwise they are d-separated".

So if the path is collider-free, direction and, therefore, where we start from does not matter.
But isn't the path between Palate and Moxie directed (though it's collider-free)? Or do we simply assume that if there are no collisions that we can start the path from either node?

Sort of like the latter. Direction still matters for calculating the actual probabilities. But for d-connection either is fine. This slide from lecture 13 might help more ![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
In that case, doesn't that mean that 2b and 2e in the primer are basically the same question?
Not exactly since in 2E we are asking about Enrolled.
Sorry, I meant 2b and 2d. Wouldn't they be basically asking the same question?

Oh, they are similar but 2D is asking what if we now know P and M so your answer might be different. This slide might help.

title: Homework 5 Primer Question 1
body:
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

For this question do we assume that we are already in the dining room state and discovering the house from there? Also does reaching the garage terminates our exploration? 
Or our start state is front porch and we are finding different ways to reach the dining room? I am confused.

comments.body:
The garage state is a terminal state, so by definition, it terminates our exploration.

For this particular question, we are asking for a description transition function from the Dining Room. Recall from the lecture, P(s'|s,a) is the probability of going to state s' given that we are at state s and take action a. So what we are asking you is to describe the probability of reaching some state s' given we are in the dining room and take action a.  Perhaps one thing to initially think about that might help is what is P(s'=bathroom | s= dining room, a) for any action a.

title: How is this value calculated in lecture 17 (MDP)?
body:
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

Here's how I tried calculating this value:
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/17cda193-edc7-46d3-9ee4-969df8027cb7/deb0731b-4a92-4fa4-b3bb-1af9b8a0a886/image.png)

Is there something that I'm missing? R(3,3) = 0 so I'm not sure how 0.78 is achieved.

conversation.name: How is this value calculated in lecture 17 (MDP)?

comments.body:
0 + .9(.1 * .72 + .1 * 0 + .8 * 1) = .7848
It is based entirely on the values of the previous iteration. If you go right, there is a chance that you stay in the same spot, U1(3, 3) = .72. You could also go down which in the previous iteration had a utility of 0. Or go right which we know is utility of 1.

title: Policy Convergence Clarification
body:
"That is, at what iteration of value iteration did the policy generated by each iterations’ values stop changing?" 

Is this asking 
a) at which iteration did we start seeing the final policy 

or 

b) at which iteration was the policy the same as the one before it, and was the final policy. 


For example, if I had the policies after some number of iterations,  
0: up
1: up 
2: right 
3: down
4: down
5: down
...
infinity: down

Would the policy converge at the 3rd iteration or the 4th iteration in this case?

comments.body:
I would say b) is more accurate. Depending on how you interpret a), it could imply in your example that if we see "up" at iteration 21 and then "dow"n again until infinity, we might incorrectly give the answer of the 3rd or 4th iteration.

Either way, for your given example, 3rd or 4th would be fine. We made it so both answers are correct when grading.

title: HW5 Coding Question 3
body:
Question 3 states that:
"Modify the parameters in your code so that state (2, 2) has a reward of -100 and replace the None values for the variables gridworld, EPSILON, and discount_factor in the  q3()function in answers.py and run it."

However in the 4 multiple-choice options, they seem to keep mentioning that the state having the reward of -100 is state (1, 2) and not state (2, 2):

a.	Yes, because the resulting policy will always take actions that have a 0.0 chance of reaching state (1, 2) with the big bad reward of -100. 
b.	Yes, because the resulting policy will try to ensure that we reach the goal state as quickly as possible. 
c.	No, because the negative reward from the state (1,2) is not enough to change the actions taken by the original policy.
d.	No, because the original policy already took actions that have a 0.0 chance of reaching state (1, 2) with the big bad reward of -100. 

I'm just wondering if there is a typo error here and whether that should affect my final answer? Thank you!

comments.body: Yes, see #516

So if that took say 42 iterations, then that means we'd have the table's rows 1-42.

title: Hack(H)er413 Applications are now open!
body:
Hi Everyone!

The Hack(H)er413 team would like to invite you all to participate in our fully in-person hackathon taking place on February 25th and 26th! 

Hack(H)er413 is a 24-hour student hackathon open to everyone, no matter your skill level, major, or gender identity. Our mission is to create a welcoming, inclusive and empowering environment for all women (cis and trans) and non-binary students. Students of all ethnic, gender identities, socioeconomic, and educational backgrounds are invited to come, innovate, learn, and feel safe while doing so! Participants get the opportunity to work with their peers in teams to make projects during the 24-hour window and compete for prizes in various categories. Hack(H)er413 is also hosting many workshops during the hackathon covering topics in hardware, software, and career development. Lastly, we will be hosting a career fair where students will get the opportunity to meet and network with representatives from our sponsor companies. 

We encourage anyone interested to apply right now at https://www.hackher413.com/! It is a wonderful opportunity to network with students and companies, learn new skills, and add projects to your resume. It’s also free! 

For any questions or concerns, feel free to email us at hackher413@gmail.com, and follow @hackher413 on Instagram for live updates.  

Sincerely,
The Hack(H)er413 Team

title: Question about Naive Bayes
body:
Hello, I am confused by two lecture slides for Naive Bayes Classifiers. 

Slide 52 lecture 19 says 

P(x1, x2, x3, … | spam) = P(x1 | spam) P(x2 | spam) P(x3 | spam)…

which can be simplified to 

P(attributes | spam) = P(attribute 1 | spam)P(attribute 2 | spam)...

But the next slide says 

P(class|attrs) = αP(attrs| class)P(class) = αP(class)
∏
i
P(attri| class)

As far as I can tell these are the exact same equations on the right side, but the conditional probabilities on the left are reversed. I.E P(attributes | class) became P(class | attributes) Why is this happening? Is this a typo?

comments.body:
$$P(class|attributes) = \frac{P(attributes|class) P(class)}{P(attributes)}$$ by Bayes Rule

We defined it so that $$\alpha = \frac{1}{P(attributes)}$$ as well as assuming all attributes are independent so $$P(attributes|class) = P(attr_1|class) *P(attr_2|class)...=\prod{P(attr_{i}|class)}$$

Substituting we get $$P(class|attributes) = \alpha P(class)\prod{P(attr_{i}|class)}$$

So the next slide hasn't quite reversed the conditions but used the simplification from the previous slide. Also, keep in mind that what we want is to find $$P(class|attributes)$$

body:
Hi,
It seems like the gradescope expects certain attributes to be in place for the root level and second level of the tree.

I think I have the same issue leading me to fail only these test cases.
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

From what I understand, the way the autograder tests this is we train both your decision tree and our decision tree on the entire data set (no train/test splitting is done). Then, in theory, your tree should have the same structure as our tree.

title: When to stop splitting
body: If we find that the optimal split creates a node with too few entries, should stop down that path at all or should we try a different attribute to split on to see if we get a split where both sides have enough examples?

comments.body: You stop splitting when either the information gain is useless or when none of the splits lead to children with greater than `min_leaf_count` examples.
Can you clarify when the information gain is useless? What value should an information gain be for it to be useless? What is the threshold for useless?

Information gain is the difference between the entropy of the parent and the weighted average entropy of the children. We want to make sure our split decreases the entropy (you can think of entropy as "uncertainty"). A good split will ensure that the averaged entropy amongst the split data is lowered. Because of this, as long as information gain is positive, we have an informative split (this is because we are decreasing the average entropy).

Isn't the information gain always positive? In the formula for entropy, it is using the log base 2 of a probability which range from 0 to 1 so the output of the log is always negative so the entropy is always positive. I do not see a case where the information gain could be negative ever. Are you perhaps saying the case where the information gain is 0?

title: Quiz 2 Question
body:
![Screen%20Shot%202022-12-12%20at%207.22.01%20AM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

Why is the answer never? Isn't it possible for local search to find the optimal solution if it gets lucky?

comments.body:
What I understand is, even though your local search (let say, in the case of finding the highest hill) reach the optimal result (reach the highest hill, in this case), you still can't prove if this value is optimal, because you never test to find if there is more optimal value globally. 

That is, no matter if you are lucky enough such that you just find the highest hill at your local search at your first time searching, if you don't run any more times with randomization, you still can't prove that the hill you have found  is the really optimal one. 

HTH :)

It will be possible for a local search to find the optimal solution if there is randomization. A local search without randomization does not always optimize to the optimal solution as a local search does not keep track of past results, thus, having no data to compare to. Instead, in question Q1.4, a local search can return an optimal solution with stochastic hill climbing, which is an optimization algorithm that makes use of randomness as part of the search process.

title: Homework 6 coding
body:
The pdf with the instructions for the coding portion of the homework states that we should not consider a split that results in a set with less than the min_leaf_count. That would mean, len(set) >= min_leaf_count is a valid split. After incorporating that into my code, I failed the 'Test min_leaf_count functionality' test. Changing the code to len(set) > min_leaf_count fixed it. 
Should we, therefore, ignore the instructions and say that we should not consider a split that results in a set with less than or equal to the min_leaf_count?

comments.body: I implemented it as if len(set) >= min_leaf_count is a valid split. My code passes public gradescope tests.

title: Attribute error
body:
![Screenshot%202022-12-13%20at%2010.23.35%20PM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

Please help, do not know what is wrong...

comments.body: I believe it is because the basic test data file found on Moodle used on those test have an attribute called 'id' and it should be ignored. Your code isn't ignoring it so it causes the error. Looking up "id_name" in decision_tree.py should help.
Thanks for replying, but I did check all my codes, and did not find any place I have used "id_name". I belive I did ignore it though please advise.

Ah, then in that case you were supposed to use it. When we iterate through the attributes, we want to make sure we skip the attribute whose name is the same as the value that will be stored in "id_name". So in your "findtheBestAttributes" when you have 
```
if header == self.class_name or header == 'Town':
    continue
```
You'd also want to check if header is equal to self.id_name. 

In the towns dataset there is no id so id_name isn't used.  However, the autograder is also tested on the basic test dataset which has an id named "id", so we have that self.id_name="id". Your code doesn't skip the "id" column and continue to the column named "first", thus giving the error.
Nick, Thank you so much!

title: Quick Beam Search Question
body:
In local beam search, part of the procedure is to:

At each iteration, generate the successors of all k states
- If anyone is a goal state, stop; otherwise, select the k best
successors from the complete list and repeat 

Does 'k best successors' here mean the 1 best successor for each k states? Or the k best successors out of all successors generated from all k states?

Thanks for the clarification

comments.body: All the states are pooled, and the k best are selected from that.
Thanks.

title: Primer 1 question 6
body:
Given two admissible heuristics, h1(s) and h2(s), if h1(s) > h2(s) for all s, which heuristic
will perform better? Why?
The answer given on grade scope is just H1 but doesn't explain why I am wondering if anyone could explain why this is.

comments.body: We know both are admissible which means both underestimate the true cost from the node to the goal node. At that point, we would prefer the one that is larger since it is closer to the true cost of the path from that node to the goal.

lecture 2 slide 84 " A “tighter” heuristic will be less optimistic, allowing us to 
de-prioritize (and therefore ignore) more potential paths 
stemming from states in the frontier. "

title: Quiz 5
body:
Why might this be wrong?
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

comments.body: KB doesn't necessarily always have to be true whenever alpha is true. However, KB can't be true when alpha is false, which is why "alpha is true under all models where KB is true" is the right answer, because that implies that KB is strictly a subset of alpha - and hence the KB can't take true values when alpha doesn't.
I see. Thank you.

title: Probability primer!
body:
![Screen%20Shot%202022-12-14%20at%207.16.36%20PM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
Can someone tell me how they solve this one?
Thanks!

comments.body:
You can rewrite P(m, a) using marginalization:
P(m, a, p, e) + P(m, a, -p, e) + P(m, a, p, -e) + P(m, a, -p, -e)

Then, just rewrite each of the joint prob terms above as a conditional probability of each variable given it's parents and plug in the appropriate values from the CPTs.

title: Inference by enumeration
body:
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

I understand how we did join R, but can't understand join T. Can someone explain how we got P(R,T,L) by doing join T on P(R,T) ,and P(L|T)?

In order to get P(R,T,L), will we not need to do P(L | T ,R) X P(R, T)?

comments.body: Yeah so any node is conditionally independent of its non-descendants given its parents and L's only parent is T. As a result we only need to multiply P(R, T) by P(L|parents) = P(L|T) instead of by P(L| R, T).
Oh that makes sense, thank you!

Isn't it the case that we need to multiply P(L|T) by P(T), not by P(R,T)? It seems as if values in the P(R,T) table are being directly multiplied with numbers in the P(L|T) table. Why can we do this? Why do we not need to marginalize T first?

Start with the basic conditional probability rule that P(A|B) = P(A, B) / P(B).

Rearrange, P(A, B) = P(A|B)P(B). Following this rule with our bayes net, P(L, R, T) = P(L|R, T)P(R, T). Since L is conditionally independent of R given parent T, we know P(L|R,T) is actually equivalent to P(L|T), as R being considered does not impact it.

This is why we can multiply P(L|T) * P(R, T). I think?!
I see! That seems like a good explanation. Thanks.

title: Hw2 Primer
body:
What is the solution of this question?

What would the above quantity be for a Connect-383 game played with m rows and n columns? Write your answer in terms of m and n rather than b and d.

Thanks

comments.body: There are a total of m*n possible moves as you have m rows and n columns. The player can, however, only choose the column and not the row thereby making n possible choices. Therefore, instead of O(b^d), the branching factor b becomes n, and the depth is mn which means the final answer is O(n^(mn)).Hope this helps

title: Approximate inference
body: In what ways is Rejection sampling better than Likelihood Weighting?

comments.body: It’s not. It just avoids unecessary sample creation.

Rejection sampling can easily be parallelized and can be used to generate samples from any distribution, regardless of whether it is easy to directly sample from the distribution. 

Likelihood sampling is better in cases where you can save time by not generating rejected samples in the first place.
